newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Costello says c/a holds back Australia growth.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Costello says c/a holds back Australia growth.

text.p: Australian Treasurer Peter Costello said on Monday that Australia's savings-investment imbalance was causing it a problem on the current account, which in turn was restricting the country's ability to grow.

"...We need to grow the Australian economy at four percent plus over the long term to make the kind of economic development that we want in this country," Costello told a meeting of the Business Council of Australia in Sydney.
"And yet we found every time that growth took off in Australia the current account deficit blew out and we were forced to pare it back," he said.
"If we want to grow the Australian economy on a sustainable basis we've got to attack the underlying problem of our low savings ratios," Costello said.
He said the continual running of government deficits had been a major factor behind the savings-investment imbalance.
The Coalition government was determined to turn things around, as outlined in its August 20 budget, Costello said.

He also said the view of Australia and Australian inflation prospects was changing, noting that since the election on March 2 the yield differential between U.S. and Australian bonds had fallen 130 basis points.
"The view of Australia and Australian inflation prospects is changing ... we are bringing rewards," Costello said.
Australia had a budget deficit of A$10.3 billion in the year to June. The government is aiming for a deficit of A$5.65 billion in 1996/97 and hopes to have a small surplus by 1998/99.
The current account deficit for 1995/96 was A$20.54 billion. The government forecasts a deficit of A$20 billion for the current fiscal year.
In the year to June, year average annual consumer inflation was 4.2 percent. The government is forecasting 2.0 percent for the current fiscal year.
Inflation figures for the September quarter are due on Wednesday.
